intro: Megalastrum brevipubens, commonly known as the short-hairless mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and white, waxy flowers. The plant lacks true roots and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while photosynthesis occurs through its leaves. It is native to parts of Southeast Asia and is often found in tropical and subtropical forests. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have a significant impact on the health of its host trees.
